conversation.content: [shaky voice] You said on the phone that you found something underneath the paint layers of Emma's self-portrait, something she deliberately hid before she— [pause] I've been standing outside this lab for twenty minutes trying to work up the courage to come in.

[hesitantly] The infrared spectroscopy revealed extensive underpainting, words and images she covered with thick layers of oils. [quietly] I've been doing this work for fifteen years, and I've never seen someone use a canvas like a diary the way your sister did.
[anxious] Emma always said that painting was the only time she felt real, like her actual self could finally breathe. [sighs] We were identical twins, but I never understood what she meant until now.

[carefully] The messages progress chronologically from the bottom layers upward, starting about six months before her death. [clearing throat] Some of them mention you specifically, things she wanted to say but couldn't.
[crying while speaking] What kind of things? [very quietly] I keep thinking if I'd just paid more attention, if I hadn't been so wrapped up in my own life, maybe I would have seen the signs.

She wrote 'My twin lives in daylight while I drown in paint fumes and shadows' across the entire bottom layer. [pause] There's also a sketch of two girls holding hands that she covered with black paint.
We used to hold hands everywhere as kids, even in high school until people started making fun of us. [bitter] I was the one who pulled away first, said we needed to grow up and be individuals.

[empathetically] The chemical analysis shows she returned to this painting repeatedly, adding layers whenever she was struggling. [softly] The final layer, applied just days before, contains a single word repeated seventeen times.
[barely audible] What word? [shaky voice] Please, I need to know everything she couldn't tell me when she was alive, even if it destroys me.
[very quietly] 'Sister' written over and over in cadmium red, the most expensive pigment she owned. [sighs] She mixed it with tears, we can tell from the salt crystals that formed as it dried.
[monotone] She called me three times that last week, but I was at a conference in Seattle and kept sending her to voicemail. [laughs bitterly] I texted her that we'd catch up when I got back.
[gently] There's more.

[desperate] Every therapist keeps telling me survivor's guilt is normal for twins, that I couldn't have known, but they didn't see her painting becoming darker month by month. [exhales] I saw everything and did nothing.
[pause] Should I continue?
[firmly] Yes, tell me all of it. [crying while speaking] I owe her that much at least, to witness what she needed me to see when it mattered.

[slowly] Beneath the repeated 'sister' text, in the deepest layer we could access without damaging the canvas, she painted both your faces but gave you her eyes and herself yours. [very quietly] The inscription reads 'We were supposed to share everything, even this.'
[gasping] Oh god, she thought about taking me with her? [shaky voice] Is that what she meant? That we should have died together?

[carefully] I think she meant the pain, that she wanted to share the pain with you but couldn't figure out how. [sighs] The technical notes indicate she spent over a hundred hours just on those exchanged eyes.
[whispering] Can I touch it? [louder] The painting, I mean, just once where her hands were, where she pressed her feelings into the canvas?

[warmly] Normally I'd say absolutely not, but in this case, yes. [softly] Your sister embedded so much of herself in these layers that perhaps she'd want you to feel what she couldn't say. [pause] Here, put on these gloves first.
